I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 

 
1. 
to the Republic of Tajikistan for the Road Network Sustainability Project. 
 
2. 
The  project  will  enhance  connectivity,  safety,  sustainability,  and  women’s  livelihoods  in 
southern  Tajikistan  by  (i)  rehabilitating  two  existing  road  sections:  Dangara–Okmazor  and 
Hulbuk–Kangurt; (ii) supporting the Ministry of Transport (MOT) to operationalize its road asset 
management  system  (RAMS);  and  (iii)  providing  an  empowerment  program  to  women  on 
business development and household financial management.1 The project augments the efforts 
of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help strengthen international and national road networks 
in the country, leading to inclusive economic growth and promoting regional connectivity. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Importance of road transport to Tajikistan’s development. Tajikistan is landlocked and 
bordered by Afghanistan, the People’s Republic of China, the Kyrgyz Republic, and Uzbekistan. 
The country had a gross domestic product (GDP) per capita of $871 in 2019, and the poverty rate 
in the country is about 27% of the total population.2 Most of the population categorized as poor 
live in rural areas that are isolated from main economic mainstream because of underdeveloped 
transport  networks.  Because  of  underdeveloped  railway  and  aviation  subsectors,  the  country 
relies heavily on road transport for international and domestic movement of goods and people. 
 
4. 
Need  for  balanced  development  of  the  road  network.  The  road  network  under  the 
MOT’s  jurisdiction  totals  14,339  kilometers  (km),  comprising  3,348  km  of  international  roads 
(23%), 2,127 km of national roads (15%), and 8,864 km of local roads (62%). About 77% of roads 
are paved.3 To strengthen connectivity with surrounding countries, the government has prioritized 
improving  international  highway  networks,  which  comprise  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic 
Cooperation  (CAREC)  corridors  2,  3,  5,  and  6  and  Asian  Highway  (AH)  7,  AH65,  and  AH66.4 
Most of these international roads are in good or fair condition. On the other hand, national roads 
have  deteriorated  and  remain  unsafe  because  of  disaster-prone  topography,  dysfunctional 
maintenance systems, overloaded trucks, and the poor quality of the original construction works 
carried out in the 1970s. 
 
Weak economic and physical connectivity in southern Tajikistan. Unbalanced road 
5. 
development is reflected in the poor state of roads in the southern oblast (province) of Khatlon. 
With  37.2%  of  the  country’s  population,  it  is  the  country’s  most  populous  oblast.  It  is  also  the 
country’s  largest  agricultural  producer.  For  these  reasons,  the  oblast  is  critical  to  the  overall 
economic  growth  of  Tajikistan.  Meanwhile,  the  poverty  rate  in  the  oblast  is  the  highest  in  the

 country,  while  the  human  development  and  income  indexes  are  the  lowest. 5 Poor  transport 
infrastructure is a key factor behind these socioeconomic challenges. 
 
6. 
Several  international  corridors  traverse  South  Tajikistan,  including  AH66  and  CAREC 
corridors 5 and 6. Most of the corridors have been rehabilitated with the assistance of ADB and 
other  development  partners  and  facilitate  the  region’s  economic  development  by  linking  major 
economic  centers.6 However,  national  roads  connecting  these  international  corridors  have  not 
been well developed, limiting the local population’s use of these corridors. The project will address 
the  immediate  needs  for  strengthening  domestic  connectivity  by  improving  two  national  road 
sections: (i)  Dangara–Okmazor  and (ii)  Hulbuk–Kangurt.  These sections  are  vital  as they  both 
link up with AH66 (at Dangara and Hulbuk). Furthermore, the Dangara–Okmazor section is part 
of a key corridor intersecting with CAREC corridors 5 and 6 at Bokhtar; and the Hulbuk–Kangurt 
section serves as a local economic corridor passing through the region’s key economic centers. 
Traffic volume on the Hulbuk–Kangurt road is about 1,300 vehicles per day in 2020, while traffic 
volume on the Dangara–Okmazor section is about 4,200 vehicles per day.7 At completion, the 
sections  will  form  a  new  economic  network  around  Dangara,  which  the  government  plans  to 
develop as the oblast’s new capital city.8 Despite their strategic importance, these sections have 
not been equipped with sufficient road safety facilities and disaster-proof measures. Inadequate 
road maintenance has led to their continuous deterioration and to heavy dust pollution. Improving 
the  sections  would  strengthen  economic  connectivity  in  southern  Tajikistan,  enhance  people’s 
access to socioeconomic opportunities, and reduce local dust pollution. 
 
7. 
system. 
Underdevelopment of the country’s road network has been compounded by long-standing neglect 
of  road  maintenance,  with  insufficient  budget  allocations  and  an  absence  of  a  well-developed 
RAMS. The annual budget for routine road maintenance throughout the year and snow removal 
during winter seasons has risen from TJS34.0 million in 2010 to TJS73.2 million in 2020. However, 
this accounts for only about 0.1% of GDP, and is insufficient to cover actual needs. Given the 
resource  constraints,  several  development  partners,  including  ADB,  have  assisted  the 
government in optimizing the use of limited resources and eliminating the inefficiencies arising 
from mechanical allocation of the budget. With ADB support, the country has introduced a RAMS 
and piloted performance-based road maintenance.9 The pilot revealed several issues that need 
to be overcome prior to expanding such schemes: (i) strengthening the government’s capacity for 
proper implementation, (ii) strengthening local contractors’ capacities to carry out maintenance, 
and (iii) pursuing flexibility in contracting schemes. To overcome such challenges in a step-wise 
manner, the government, with support from ADB, is developing a RAMS Action Program that will 
institutionalize a RAMS and establish a dedicated road maintenance fund to secure budget for 
road maintenance. The government is expected to approve the RAMS Action Program in 2020. 
A dedicated RAMS unit is expected to be established by the end of 2020 to implement the RAMS 
Action Program, while the road maintenance fund will be established by June 2024.  
 
8. 
Critical  need  to  improve  road  safety.  The  World  Health  Organization  estimates  that 
there were 1,577 fatalities from road crashes in 2016, which equates to 18.1 fatalities per 100,000

to  raise  people’s  awareness  of  road  safety,  promote  behavioral  change,  and  embed  crash

international best practices collated through CAREC.13 
 
Addressing disaster risk. Tajikistan is one of the countries most vulnerable to climate 
9. 
change in Central Asia. Its unique terrain, geology, and hydrological features make it prone to 
natural  disasters  and  hazards.  Specific  to  the  project  area,  the  climate  change  assessment 
identified  rising  temperatures  and  intense  precipitation  as  major  potential  causes  of  extreme 
climate events, such as landslides and mudflows.14 Climate adaptation features were therefore 
incorporated into the design of the project roads. 
 
10. 
Alignment  with  government  strategies.  The  project  is  aligned  with  the  government’s 
National Development Strategy, which targets sustainable economic growth of Tajikistan.15 The 
project is also in line with the Transport Sector Master Plan,16 developed with ADB assistance in 
2011  as  the  basis  for  the  government’s  strategic  sector  planning.  The  project  will  contribute 
directly to the State Program on Transport Sector Development, 2010–2025,17 which includes a 
list of short-, medium-, and long-term investments that is regularly reviewed and updated, and 
aims to further the country’s transport sector development by enhancing the efficiencies of various 
transport modes, maximizing the country’s transit potential, and increasing the competitiveness 
of  transport  services.  Furthermore,  the  project  will  address  climate  vulnerability  (para.  9)  in 
accordance  with  Tajikistan’s  Intended  Nationally  Determined  Contribution,18 which  emphasizes 
the need for incorporating climate adaptation measures in the design of transport infrastructure. 
The  project  also  supports  the  United  Nations’  Vienna  Programme  of  Action  for  Landlocked 
Developing Countries for the Decade of 2014–2024.19 
 
Strategic fit. The project is fully aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030.20 It supports four of 
11. 
the  strategy’s  seven  operational  priorities:  (i)  addressing  remaining  poverty  and  reducing 
inequalities (para. 36); (ii) accelerating progress in gender equality (para. 37); (iii) tackling climate 
change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability 
(para. 26); and (iv) fostering regional cooperation and integration, prioritizing countries that face 
geographic and disaster-related vulnerabilities (paras. 9 and 12). The project is fully in line with

in its strategic objectives. 
 
Promoting  regional  connectivity.  The  project  will  contribute  to  the  goals  of  CAREC 
12. 
203023 and  the  CAREC  Transport  Strategy  2030  by  improving  connectivity  and  improving  the 
competitiveness of key national roads that connect to international corridors (para. 6).24 In 2019, 
Tajikistan acceded to the Convention on the Contract for the International Carriage of Goods by 
Road.  With  the  support  of  ADB,  Tajikistan  has  promoted  national  single  window  systems  that 
have increased trade volumes and diversified products transported along the country’s roads.25 
The project will help accelerate the momentum for turning southern Tajikistan into an international 
and domestic transit and business hub. 
 
13. 
Lessons.  Lessons  from  previous  and  ongoing  projects  (footnote  6)  include:  (i)  the 
accuracy  of  engineering  designs  and  cost  estimates  for  road  infrastructure  and  associated 
facilities should be ensured during project appraisal, (ii) executing and implementation agencies 
should have a proper understanding of ADB’s procurement procedures and requirements, and 
(iii) developing a RAMS is an urgent need for Tajikistan’s road transport subsector to sustain the 
quality of the improved international highway network. 
 
Impact  of  coronavirus  disease.  The  coronavirus  disease  (COVID-19)  pandemic  has 
14. 
weakened  Tajikistan’s  economy  and  increased  unemployment  and  poverty.  In  response  to 
COVID-19,  the  government  imposed  a  nationwide  lockdown  that  lasted  about  2  months,  with 
closures of all airports. Overseas remittances, international trade, and foreign direct investment 
all declined.26 Food prices increased.27 The pandemic has exacerbated the many socioeconomic 
challenges in the project area, which relies heavily on external support being delivered via the 
existing road network. The project-supported road improvements will be essential to reversing the 
recent economic downward trend. Measures are in place to minimize the impact of COVID-19 on 
project implementation. Under the project, civil works will commence in early 2021, by which time 
it  is  expected  that  the  spread  of  COVID-19  will  have  subsided  because  of  the  government’s 
continuing response measures. However, if the spread of COVID-19 continues and domestic and 
international  travel  remain  restricted,  the  MOT  and  the  Project  Implementation  Unit  for  Roads 
Rehabilitation  (PIURR:  the  project’s  implementation  agency)  will  enact  measures  to  steadily 
mobilize resources at a reduced pace, so that construction works can continue without threatening 
the health and safety of construction workers. After completion, the improved project roads will 
play an essential role in delivering basic needs and reviving the economy in the project area.

 Project Description 

B. 
 
15. 
The project is aligned with the following impacts: (i) economic growth promoted (footnote 
15), and  (ii)  safe  and  competitive  connectivity  established  across  the  CAREC  region  (footnote 
24). The project will have the following outcome: safety and reliability of road network improved 
in southern Tajikistan.28  
 
16. 
Output  1:  Roads  in  southern  Tajikistan  improved.  This  output  will  consist  of  
(i)  rehabilitating  the  two-lane  road  sections  Dangara–Okmazor  (28.7  km)  and  Hulbuk–Kangurt 
(59.5 km) on their existing alignments, and (ii) carrying out a road-safety-awareness campaign 
for  roadside  residents.  The  two  road  sections  will  be  rehabilitated  following  their  existing 
classifications based on SNIPs.29 The classification of the Dangara–Okmazor section is category 
III (road width of 3.5 meters [m] for each lane and 2.5 m paved shoulders). The Hulbuk–Kangurt 
section  will  be  split  at  Temurmalik  into  two  subsections:  the  Hulbuk–Temurmalik  section  is 
category III,  while  Temurmalik–Kangurt section  is  category IV  (width  of 3 m for  each  lane  and  
2 m paved shoulders). The average travel speed on project road sections is expected to increase 
from 58 km per hour to 73 km per hour.  
 
17. 
Output 2: Road asset management system database developed. This output will be 
aligned  with  the  MOT’s  RAMS  Action  Program  (para.  7)  and  will  support  the  MOT  in 
operationalizing its RAMS by developing a data inventory of the country’s arterial highways. The 
MOT maintains no comprehensive inventory, making it difficult to estimate maintenance needs 
and plan the optimal use of available resources. ADB has coordinated with development partners 
in  developing  a  framework  for  a  RAMS  database. 30 An  international  consultancy  firm  will  be 
recruited to help the RAMS unit to collect condition data for the selected highways. The firm will 
provide  hands-on  training  to  the  RAMS  unit  staff  on  (i)  preparing  formats  for  data  collection,  
(ii)  carrying  out  road  condition  surveys,  (iii)  validating  the  collected  data  for  entering  into  the 
database, and (iv) analyzing the data as the basis for annual and multiyear planning. 
 
18. 
Output 3: Women’s access to socioeconomic opportunities enhanced. This output 
will  promote  women’s  participation  in  economic  activities  in  the  project  area  through  three 
components: 
implementing  a  knowledge  distribution  program  on 
entrepreneurship and household financial management, (ii) providing skills training on business 
development  and  income-generation  activities  in  areas  of  high  business  demand,  and  
(iii) facilitating local women’s access to grants for starting new business. A local consulting firm 
will help implement the output in coordination with the National Committee of Women and Family 
Affairs. As part of the first component, mobile phone applications or short message services will 
be devised to distribute the contents of the knowledge distribution program, enabling local women 
to obtain information at their convenience.31 Supplementary workshops will be held regularly to 
recap the knowledge distributed and foster mutual-aid networks among the participants. 
 
19. 
Lessons  from  previous  and  ongoing  projects  (para.  13)  were  taken  into  account  in  the

III.

DUE DILIGENCE

Road design. The rehabilitation of roads will be carried out along existing rights-of-way
26.
(without  involving  expansion)  as  road  widths  have  been  confirmed  to  be  sufficient  to
accommodate  the  anticipated  increases  in  traffic  volumes.  Asphalt  concrete  surfacing  will  be
used,  and  its  design  was  confirmed  to  suit  existing  roadbed  soil  conditions  and  to  be  able  to
withstand  the  forecasted  traffic  load.  The  engineering  design  will  incorporate  climate-resilient
features to sustain the quality of the project roads and roadside facilities during their design life.
Such features are incorporated in the design of retaining walls, drainages and ditches based on
the  possibility  of  extreme  precipitation  and  subsequent  landslides  or  mudflows  in the  next  100
years. Roadside facilities such as shoulders, sidewalks, and lighting will be improved or newly
installed to ensure road users’ safety and comfort. These features have been selected in close
coordination with local traffic police.

B.

Economic and Financial Viability

27.
The  economic  evaluation  of  the  project  has  been  undertaken  using  the  highway
development and management model, in accordance with ADB guidelines.34 The due diligence
consultant obtained traffic volumes for the evaluation in May 2020.35 An economic evaluation was
made for each road section, and these were combined to confirm the project’s overall economic
viability.  The  incremental  benefits  of  reductions  in  vehicle  operating  costs,  travel  times,  and
emissions were compared with the capital costs and changes in operation and maintenance costs
over a 27-year appraisal period, comprising 2 years for civil works and 25 years  for operation.
Road safety benefits were excluded from the analysis since credible data was not available. All
project benefits were expressed in 2020 economic prices, in United States dollars, using the world
price numeraire.

28.
The results indicate that the combined project is economically viable, with an economic
internal  rate  of  return  of  15.7%,  a  benefit–cost  ratio  of  1.9,  and  a  net  present  value  of  $46.4
million.36 Sensitivity tests confirmed that the combined project would remain feasible should the
envisaged project costs increase by 20% or benefits decline by 20%.37

C.

Sustainability

The  project  roads  will  not  be  tolled  and  will  not generate  revenue.  After civil  works  are
29.
completed, they will be maintained under the government’s maintenance program. The required
routine maintenance expenditure for the project roads will total about $1,900 per km per year after
completion.  The  current  budget  allocation  for  the  country’s  road  network  will  barely  cover  this
routine maintenance, let alone the additional periodic maintenance that will be required every 5–
7  years.  Insufficient  maintenance  funds  is  by  far  the  most  serious  issue  threatening  the
sustainability of the project roads.

To  tackle  these  long-standing  challenges,  the  government,  in  parallel  with  its  effort  to
30.
secure  more  budget  resources  for  road  maintenance,  has  redoubled  its  efforts  to  establish  a
RAMS  through  its  5-year  RAMS  Action  Program  (para.  7).  The  program  clearly  outlines  the
following directions to transform the country’s road maintenance system: (i) establishing a RAMS
unit  within the MOT  with  the  sole responsibility  to  implement the  program;  (ii)  streamlining the
budgetary system by establishing a dedicated road maintenance fund to secure budget funds for

annual  maintenance  plan  and  budget.  The  project  will  directly  contribute  to  item  (iii).
Implementation of the RAMS Action Program is expected to be completed by 2024—the year of

improved  its  fiscal  and  institutional  capacity  to  meet  recurrent  expenditures  and  adequately
operate and maintain the project roads over the economic life of the project.38

D.

Governance

Financial management. The due diligence consultant (footnote 35) undertook a financial
31.
management assessment of the PIURR in June 2020, confirming that its financial management
arrangement is appropriate to implement the project in compliance with ADB requirements. The
assessed pre-mitigation financial management risk is substantial because of the PIURR’s existing
financial  management  system,  which  remains  the  same  from  the  previous  assessment.  The
PIURR has built on its experience implementing ADB-financed projects, and improvements have
been made with an adequate accounting manual in place and accounting software (1C)39 fully
operationalized.  PIURR’s  residual  weaknesses  in  financial  management  are  (i)  insufficient
financial management skills, including limited technical capacity and experience to transition to
International  Financial  Reporting  Standards;  (ii)  inadequate  formalization  of  operational
procedures, including no explicit policy to report inappropriate asset management; (iii) absence
of  internal  audit  function;  and  (iv)  an  unintegrated  accounting  system.  To  mitigate  such
weaknesses, the PIURR will (i) hire adequately qualified and skilled financial management staff
to support the transition to International Financial Reporting Standards and undertake training on
financial management, (ii) develop and implement a comprehensive operations manual, (iii) bring
itself within the scope of the MOT’s internal audit process in consultation with the MOT and MOF,
and (iv) accelerate the integration of the accounting system. The PIURR will maintain adequate
and  separate  project  records  and  accounts,  which  will  be  audited  annually  by  independent
auditors.

E.

Poverty, Social, and Gender

36. With  help  of  the  due  diligence  consultant,  the  government  carried  out  socioeconomic
surveys  and  a  gender  assessment  in  May–July  2020  to  identify  the  issues  and  needs  of  the
population, including women, residing along the project roads.41 The project area is in the poorest
and most populous oblast in the country (para. 5). The majority of the population along the project
roads are engaged in the informal economy, mainly farming activities and/or selling agricultural
commodities  (cotton,  vegetables,  and  fruits)  or  hand-made  products  at  markets.  Such  an
economic structure has been observed as being vulnerable to external shocks like COVID-19.42
Improving the  project  roads  will help  attract  external  traders from  outside  the  project  area  and
boost and diversify trade to generate more economic opportunities in a sustainable manner. The
project roads and roadside facilities will reduce road traffic fatalities and injuries, and will improve
the comfort and reliability of road travel for all users.43

The  project  is  categorized  effective  gender  mainstreaming.  The  project  will  address
37.
gender issues identified through group discussions focused on women during project preparation.

road  safety  measures  on  the  project  roads  and  limited  opportunities  to  participate  in  the  local
